content: The Act is titled the "Government Shutdown Prevention Act" and includes an amendment to Title 31. The "Government Shutdown Prevention Act" includes an amendment to Title 31, specifically adding a new section for continuing appropriations in case regular appropriation bills are not passed before the fiscal year begins. The "Government Shutdown Prevention Act" allows for continuing appropriations at a rate of operations not exceeding 75 percent of the previous fiscal year's funding levels. The "Government Shutdown Prevention Act" allows for continuing appropriations at a rate not exceeding 75 percent of the previous fiscal year's funding levels. The appropriations and funds made available for any project or activity shall be available during a lapse in appropriations. During a lapse in appropriations, funds for projects or activities will be available until the regular appropriation bill becomes law or the end of the fiscal year. Appropriations for a fiscal year will follow the terms and conditions of the previous year. During a fiscal year, obligations and expenditures for a project or activity will be covered. Expenditures must be charged to the appropriate funding source when a regular appropriation bill becomes law. This section does not apply if another law provides funding or prohibits appropriations for the project. The term 'regular appropriation bill' refers to annual bills that allocate funds for various categories of projects and activities, including agriculture, rural development, defense, and government operations in the District of Columbia. This section does not apply if another law already provides funding or prohibits appropriations for the project. The curr_chunk lists various activities chargeable against District revenues, including departments like Labor, Health, Education, Housing, Urban Development, Energy, Water Development, Foreign Assistance, Interior, Military Construction, Transportation, Treasury, Postal Service, and the legislative branch. A clerical amendment is made to chapter 13 of title 31. A clerical amendment is made to chapter 13 of title 31, United States Code, inserting a new item after section 1310. The amendments made by this Act regarding continuing appropriations do not affect government obligations mandated by other laws, such as Social Security, Medicare, and Medicaid. The amendments will apply starting from fiscal year 1998 and will expire after 5 years from the enactment date of the Act.
